title: Wilhelm Peterson-Berger
text:
Olof Wilhelm Peterson-Berger ( 27 February 1867, <a href="Ull%C3%A5nger">Ullånger</a> — 3 December 1942, <a href="%C3%96stersund">Östersund</a>) was a <a href="Swedes">Swedish</a> <a href="composer">composer</a> and <a href="music%20critic">music critic</a>. As a composer, his main musical influences were <a href="Edvard%20Grieg">Grieg</a>, <a href="August%20S%C3%B6derman">August Söderman</a> and <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Wagner</a> as well as Swedish folk idiom.
The composer.
Peterson-Berger studied at the <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a> Conservatory from 1886–89 and then in <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a> for a year.
He is best known for three albums of <a href="Romantic%20nationalism">national romantic</a> <a href="piano">piano</a> pieces entitled "Frösöblomster I, II and III" ("Flowers of Frösö"), which includes the often performed "Vid Frösö kyrka" ("At Frösö Church") and "Sommarsång" ("Summer Song"). The sets, which were composed over a period of 18 years (1896 - 1914) and brought together afterwards as a collection have gained a reputation of representing a quintessential "Swedishness" in the romantic, nationalistic vein of their time. The most famous of the pieces, "Sommarsång" ("Summer Song") recalls the warm, calm, harmonious and bright pre-summer evenings where the sun in the north almost never goes down; they were the great breakthrough for Wilhelm. "Sommarsång" is still known to most Swedes, even to people generally uninterested in music: the majority of young piano students in the Nordic countries have been taught this piece. His songs for vocal ensemble are also still regularly performed, and are part of the core repertoire of Swedish choirs.
His other works include the five <a href="Symphony">symphonies</a> - among them are no.2 "Sunnanfärd" and no.3 "<a href="Sami%20people">Same-Ätnam</a>" generally considered the best - as well as the <a href="opera">opera</a>s "<a href="Ran%20%28Goddess%29">Ran</a>", "<a href="Arnljot%20opera">Arnljot</a>", "Domedagsprofeterna" ("The Doomsday Prophets") and "Adils och Elisiv" ("Adils and Elisiv"). His command of the larger forms, in both <a href="musical%20form">architecture</a> and <a href="instrumentation%20%28music%29">instrumentation</a>, is disputed.
He was stage manager at the Stockholm Opera from 1908-10. The opera "Arnljot" has nevertheless become something of a symbol for the province of <a href="J%C3%A4mtland">Jämtland</a> and is regularly performed there, as a "<a href="musical%20drama">musical drama</a>", at Arnljotlägden on <a href="Fr%C3%B6s%C3%B6n">Frösön</a>, close to Peterson-Berger's former home, Sommarhagen. "Domedagsprofeterna" is the antithesis of "Arnljot" – a light festive musical comedy set in 17th century <a href="Uppsala">Uppsala</a>, while the saga "Adils och Elisiv" where Swedish ‘talsång’ (speechsong) attained its purest expression is a work extolling Peterson-Berger's belief in humanism and the goodness of man.
He also wrote about eighty songs, many of which set poems by <a href="Erik%20Axel%20Karlfeldt">Erik Axel Karlfeldt</a>, for example "Aspåkers<a href="Polska%20%28dance%29">polska</a>".
Critic and writer.
As well as being a composer, Peterson-Berger was also a respected though very controversial music <a href="critic">critic</a> for the <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a> newspaper "<a href="Dagens%20Nyheter">Dagens Nyheter</a>" ("News of the Day") from 1896-1930. He was conservative and fought the increasing influence of <a href="Modernism%20%28music%29">modernism</a> in music, especially from <a href="Arnold%20Schoenberg">Arnold Schoenberg</a> and his followers. His progress was hindered by many enemies whom he made through his writings; he attacked showy virtuosity and dry academicism with satire but also with strict conscientiousness. For either composers or performers who did not conform to his taste (or who were young and insecure female musicians, to take one typical example), he was not above grave personal insults.<br> 
Other writings include ‘Svensk musikkultur’ (Swedish musical culture, 1911) which includes clearsighted and satirical attacks on the prevailing musical establishment, ‘Richard Wagner som kulturföreteelse’ (Richard Wagner as a cultural phenomenon, 1913) as well as translations of <a href="Tristan%20und%20Isolde">Tristan und Isolde</a> (for a 1909 production in Stockholm), and <a href="Friedrich%20Nietzsche">Friedrich Nietzsche</a>’s <a href="The%20Birth%20of%20Tragedy">The Birth of Tragedy</a> (1902) and <a href="Thus%20Spoke%20Zarathustra">Thus Spoke Zarathustra</a> (1919).
The man.
One acquaintance later recalled his surprise when, on a journey by train from Stockholm to Östersund and Frösön, the big man and notorious critic suddenly burst into tears and felt soft like a child as the bucolic landscape of his beloved Jämtland began to unfold outside the window. Even this writer, however, noted that even Peterson-Berger's threatening and miserable physical appearance and demeanour conformed to the stereotype of the dour Scandinavian.
His home on the island of <a href="Fr%C3%B6s%C3%B6n">Frösön</a> near Östersund (where he spent his summers from 1914 and then lived permanently from 1930) is open to the public in the summer months and is much as the composer left it. The downstairs music hall has his grand piano (he was a competent pianist), a work room (with a ‘picture window’ looking out over Storsjön) and library (with his collection of books and scores), while upstairs the bedrooms may be viewed. He lived alone there with a butler and his cats. There is also a small café where books and CDs are sold.
